comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: Definitely some "Heavy Hitters" here, men who shaped the world at that time, including President Castro.....of Venezuela!

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Jacques Loeb was a German-born American physiologist and biologist. He was one of the most famous scientists in America, widely covered in newspapers and magazines and nominated many times for the Nobel Prize.

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Joseph Chamberlain was an influential British businessman, politician, and statesman. Despite never becoming Prime Minister, he is regarded as one of the most important British politicians of the late 19th century and early 20th century, as well as a colourful character and renowned orator. He was Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's father.

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Alberto Santos-Dumont was a Brazilian aviation pioneer, who designed, built, and flew the first practical dirigible balloons. He became the first person to demonstrate that routine, controlled flight was possible. Winning the Deutsch de la Meurthe prize on October 19, 1901, on a flight that rounded the Eiffel Tower, made him one of the most famous people in the world during the early 20th century.

comment.author: 51035533664@N01
comment._content: Alberto Santos-Dumont,  a Brazilian who lived for many years in France, was an aviation pioneer who designed and built a number of successful aeroplanes in the infancy of powered flight. He is credited in 1906 with the first witnessed European takeoff, flight and landing of a heavier-than-air machine. He suffered later in his short life from MS, and died in Brazilat the relatively young age of 59.

comment._content: I wonder why the Wright brothers aren't citted on this. The Santos Dumont airplane flew with its own engine, without a catapult, and was witnessed by many, as can be seen here: www.centennialofflight.gov/essay/Commercial_Aviation/fran...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Wright Brothers aren't cited here, because the date of this paper is 1902, and Wilbur and Orville didn't make their first flight until December, 1903.
